An enthusiastic and interested
audience was present at the massmeeting held last Thursday night
in Levering Hall under the auspices of the Missionary Committee
of the Young Men's Christian Association.
• This meeting, the first of its kind,
was held to put before the University students the need for men
to become interested in mission
work. A number of mission-study
classes have been formed under
the direction of the Young Men's
Christian Association, and it was
for the purpose of getting men sufficiently interested to become members of these mission-study groups
that the mass-meeting was held.
The program, although quite extensive, was most pleasing throughout Short talks of about five minutes each were first given by Mr.
A. K. Barton, '14; Mr. Walter D.
Sutton, '14; Mr. Guy T. 0. Hollyday, '14; and Mr. Myron E. Bagley, '16.
Mr. Barton, as chairman, presented the purpose of the meeting;
Mr. Sutton spoke on "The Value
of Prayer"; Mr. Hollyday had for
his topic "The Missionary Offering from Johns Hopkins," and
told of the plan to raise one hundred dollars for missionary work;
Mr. Bagley discussed the advantages of attending the Eaglesmere
summer conference.
Other speakers were: Rev. William Levering DeVries, A. B. '88,
Ph. D. '92; Dr. Shosuke Sato, of
Japan; Dr. Heckleman, who is accompanying Dr. Sato on his lecture tour; and Dr. Frame, who has
spent the last eight years in Persia.
Rev. W. L. DeVries had for his
topic "The Call to Service in the
Mission Field." He presented a
strong appeal, showing the need of
workers in the foreign field. Dr.
Frame spoke of the opportunity for
mission work in Persia. Dr. Sato
and Dr. Heckleman both presented
the question of Christianizing Japan.
They emphasized the fact that what
is needed in Japan are missionaries
who can make an impression on the
inner life of the Japanese people,
so that the Japanese may get their
inspirations from God. Dr. Sato
made an especially strong appeal
when he said, in closing: "Gentlemen, will you all please pray that
Japan will become a Christian nation."

The seniors opened up the 1914
banquet season on last Monday
night at the Emerson. Thirty-two
of the upper classmen were present,
seated about a monster round-table.
Everyone declared that the menu
was the best ever given at a class
banquet. Certain members of the
class maintain that they ate nineteen different varieties of food, not
to say anything about the quantity
of each. Certain other members
went home Monday night with a
peculiar feeling around the equator,
and refused all invitations on Tuesday to breakfast and lunch. The
"bill of lading" included eight
courses, and very few men flunked
more than one course. While the
banqueters were busy practicalicising the theory of consumption, a
capable pianist was hard at work
tickling the ivories and putting
everyone in good spirits by the
clever and able manipulation of his
fingers.
By about 9.30 o'clock, most of
the consumers had decided that they
were quite near the limits of equilibrium, and Toastmaster C. A.
Wells was propped up, so as to be
able to direct the mass of logic(?)
that was to follow. After the usual
opening chatter of the toastmaster,
President Sutton spoke with his unusual dry humor on the "Concomitant Variations of the Class
Through the Courses of Chaucer,
Physics, Logic and Psychology."
"Long Ray" Leibensperger next extolled the ineffable, insuperable excelencies of our athletes in the
Senior Class. Bacon's "Novum
Organon" was next laid aside (on
the theory that "ham" is more substantial that bacon) and A. L. Hammond was introduced to speak on
the "Novissimum Organon" — the
1914 Hullabaloo. Kemper Simpson
next delivered the speech of the
evening. We are unable to describe in these columns what his
"dream" was about, but he may
consent to inform you if a selfaddressed, stamped envelope is
sent him. "Post hoc ergo propter
hoc," was Rev. S. D. White's text
for a sermon on the future of the
Senior Class.

The speaker at the Commemoration Day exercises this year will be
Congressman and ex-Governor Andrew Jackson Montague, of Virginia. The exercises, which usually take place on Washington's
Birthday, will be held on Monday,
February 23, owning to the fact
that the regular date falls on Sunday.
Mr. Montague is one of the most
distinguished men in Virginia today, and also one of her best-known
scholars. Graduating from Richmond College in 1882, with the degree of A. B., he pursued the law
course at the University of Virginia, receiving his LL. B. there in
1885. Four years later he married
Miss Elizabeth Lyne Hoskins, of
Carltons, Va.
The first office of state which Mr.
Montague held was that of United
States District Attorney for tile
Western District of Virginia (189498). At the close of his term he
became Attorney-General of Virginia, from which position he Was
elected governor of the State in
1902. His record while in the executive chair was brilliant and, under his guidance, many laws of lasting good to the State were passed.
Richmond College offered Mr.
Montague the deanship of its law
school in 1906, and he accepted
when his four-year term as chief
executive had expired. However,
the confinement of the academic
world was too binding upon a man
of his great vitality, and he resigned
after three years to resume his law
practice in Richmond. After his
return to private life, Mr. Montague
was successively appointed to represent the United States in Rio de
Janiero at the Pan-American Conference, and as a delegate to the
Third International Conference on
Maritime Law, held at Brussels
(1909-10). Recently he was elected to Congress, and is serving there
with honor to himself and to his
State.
Besides the high attainments of
Mr. Montague in the political

reputation as a lawyer and a

The annual McCoy Hall concert by the Musical Clubs was given
last Friday night, February 6. The
Clubs were in fine form and gave
decidedly the best performance of
this season. In the number of performers, all former records were
exceeded, since nearly every member of the unusually large Clubs
was able to take part in this home
concert. The results of this fact
were quite noticeable in the deep
volume of the Glee Club's selections, and the Instrumental Club
was also decidedly improved by the
addition of a 'cello and a bass-viol.
Aside from the fact that the program was a little longer than
pleased some of the more impatient
dancers, the whole affair may be
said to have gone off without a
hitch. The audience, considering
the unpleasant weather, was quite
large; and, judging from the applause and from the number who
stayed for the dance which immediately followed the concert, they appreciated the efforts of the entertainers.
In the first number—the University Ode—both Clubs took part, a
combination which had never been
tried before, but which proved
quite effective. The Glee Club was
most appreciated in their song,
"Mighty Lak' a Rose," in which
Mr. Scovell sang a solo part, while
the rest of the Club hummed the accompaniment. The instrumentalists,
with their popular "rags," received
hearty applause after every number. Geissel's violin solo and Gminder's performance on the 'cello were
both very well received, and later,
when the two played together, the
combination was most pleasing.
Jacobs also starred, as he always
does, in his ,performance on the
mandolin. The quartet and octet
were likewise encored several times.
The following night a picked
delegation from the two Clubs,
about twenty-five in number, gave
a concert at Hood (Woman's) College, Frederick, Md., where their
performance was very well received,
and a dance given in their honor
afterward by the juniors and freshmen of the institution. Those who
made this trip were: Eiseman,
Hayes, Boudin, Rutledge, Stollenwerck, Primrose, Weber, Hall,
Melamet, Uhler, Lynch, Lauchheimer, Beiser, Baker, Daub, Jacobs, Jenkins, Geissel, Lloyd, Coblentz, Gillet, Tappan, Bacchus and
Scovell.

THESPIAN'S LECTURE A TREAT
Mr. F. R. Benson, of the Stratford-uponAvon Players, Pleases a Large
Gathering of Students.

In an address full of deep poetical appreciation and feeling, Mr. F.
R. Benson, art director of the
Stratford-upon-Avon Players, delighted an audience of students on
Thursday afternoon in the Donovan
Room. His subject, "Song Words.
of a Nation," gave Mr. Benson a
wide field, which he covered as an
artist and a poet, rather than a
critic.
While the lecturer's specialty is
Shakespeare, and his talk led up to
the immortal bard, he carried his
hearers back to the rudiments of
poetry, its elements and its significance. The roar of the lion, the
twitter of birds—all the animal and
primitive sounds—were traced forward to their expression in Shakespeare. Instances of the different effects of rhythm were were given by
Mr. Benson, who, with great dramatic power, rendered Othello's
famous speech and the latter part
of Anthony's oration over Caesar's
body.
A more interesting lecturer would
be hard to find. In his words and
in his personality, Mr. Benson personifies not only the 'scholarly man,
but the man of wide culture and
poetical instinct, displaying histrionic ability of a high order.

No less man than the Duke of
Wellington said that the last command of Christ, "Go ye into all the
world and preach the Gospel to
every creature," constituted for
Christian men their "marching orders."
During the Spanish War, this
University was aflame with military
spirit. Companies were organized
and drills held regularly in the cage.
People paid the additional taxes
without a murmur. Newspapers
containing accounts from the front
were read with remarkable avidity.
Nothing could daunt the patriot's
zeal.
For nearly two thousand years
have been waged, with greater or
less enthusiasm, the Holy War of
Christ. Today, more than ever before, those on the "firing line" are
begging for supplies, recruits and
prayers.
"Whom shall we send, and who
will go for us," is the daily question confronting the mission boards.
N.sooner is this answered than,
"How shall they preach, except they
be sent?" is asked. To meet the
ever-increasing calls for supplies;
for recruits, for prayers, the interest of the home base has to be
kindled by more efficient means
than occasional, spasmodic missionary meetings. To know the subject
of electricity, more is required than
biennial attendance at the meetings
of a scientific association. To
know the subject of missions, one
must make a study of missions.
Moreover, it is .required of a
soldier that a man be found faithful. Faithfulness in this cause,

"dear to the heart of the Saviour,"
is synonymous with intelligent support. Intelligent support comes

Wellington said that the last command of Christ, "Go ye into all the

containing accounts from the front

zeal.

less enthusiasm, the Holy War of

begging for supplies, recruits and
prayers.

to the study of missions.

carefully selected. The Missionary
Committee asks the individual student's attendance on the courses;
and, by enlisting other men, to
make the missionary propaganda a
success.

The Quest of a Seeker.

What is the administrative plan
of the Johns Hopkins University?
What is the plan of organization
of the Board of Trustees, of the
Board of Collegiate Studies, of the
Athetic Board, of the Student Council, and how do these boards affect
the undergraduate student?
These questions should certainly
be matters of familiar knowledge to
every undergraduate. As a matter
of fact, possibly one man in every
twenty can answer any two of
them; possibly one man in every
fifty can answer all of them.
This state of affairs has given
rise to a certain feeling of suspicion
and mistrust, detrimental to a proper spirit among the students. The
Student Council took an active part
in the recent Homewood affair.
Their action was resented because
their right to act was not understood. As one man put it, "They
pop up like a Jack-in-the-box and
they disappear without leaving a
trail." Another complains of the
fact that undergraduate life is ordered by "powers that move in darkness."
Beginning next week, THE NtwsLETTER will publish the first of a
series of interviews, obtained by "a
seeker after information," with the
men at the head of the various administrative boards. The intention
of these articles is not critical nor
satirical. They aim solely to inspire a better feeling toward the
University by giving the student
a better knowledge of its plan of
organization.
